results.title: The Brown dressing gown
results.brief_description: Patric fondly remembers his social worker Julie Wilson who helped him come out of his cocoon and discard his brown dressing gown. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and The Deafness Foundation.

results.title: The Rabbit in Australia
results.brief_description: The introduction of the rabbit into Australia and the resultant long battle to contol it. Notes how the rabbit feeds, breeds and survives in different parts of Australia. No other credits available.

results.title: Peep-peep-peep
results.brief_description: Puppet animated film about the Wombles who live under Wimbledon Common in London. In this episode the Wombles discover a crude version of the telephone by using tins and string. Based on the children’s book series The Wombles by Elizabeth Beresford. Suitable for middle and upper primary level.

results.title: Emulation of Mugsy's Revenge for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
As in the original Mugsy this strategy game is presented in a highly visual style with lots of detailed comic-book style stills and short animations. As a gangster in 1919, you see an opportunity to make money by illegally supplying alcohol during the Prohibition era in the US. Hints as to all decisions in the game are given through textual conversations with your assistants - these can include how much booze to produce, how big a bribe to give, and whether to invest in your own Speakeasy bar later on.

Unlike the original game, there are some arcade sequences which involve running around and shooting down the police as they try to arrest you. The character can be hit up to 5 times but it only takes one shot to take out a cop. After each of the game’s 10 years you receive a screen updating you on your progress, as well as a special one if you and your business survives the full decade. [Sourced from https://www.mobygames.com/game/16653/mugsys-revenge//]

results.title: Videogames and Us
results.brief_description: Since videogames were first invented in laboratories, our relationship to play has evolved. From arcades and the first home consoles to todayâ€™s blockbuster releases, mobile games and experimental indies, how we interpret and experience vieogames has changed alongside us.

constellations_other.name: Arcades and AI
constellations_other.description: Using the godfather of computing, Alan Turing, as a starting point, this Constellation traces the evolution of AI representation on-screen and the way female androids, robots and holograms have been hyper sexualised.

results.description: Play is an essential part of who we are as individuals and as a collective. Since videogames were first invented by scientists in laboratories, our relationship to play has come a long way. From arcades and the first home consoles to todayâ€™s blockbuster releases, mobile games and experimental indies, videogames have evolved dramatically and so have we. How we interpret and experience videogames, and the communities and cultures spawned from them, reveals much about how society has shifted in the past five decades.
description_for_label: Play is an essential part of who we are as individuals and as a collective. Since videogames were first invented by scientists in laboratories, our relationship to play has come a long way. From arcades and the first home consoles to todayâ€™s blockbuster releases, mobile games and experimental indies, videogames have evolved dramatically and so have we. How we interpret and experience videogames, and the communities and cultures spawned from them, reveals much about how society has shifted in the past five decades.

results.title: CATARACT (concrete)
results.credit_line:
Daniel von Sturmer. Aotearoa New Zealand

Aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video. Indefinite loop

Commissioned by ACMI
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video
results.brief_description: Everyday moments of existence are presented across 60 screens as a complex cacophony of events in CATARACT (concrete). This dynamic and overwhelming assemblage reflects the abundance of moments and messages we encounter in the world, which is represented as a complex and synthesised totality.

constellations_primary.name: Now watch this
constellations_primary.description: In a video-saturated world, how do you keep focus? Do you keep a close eye on one thing, or step back and watch the parade of images go by, to see the whole thing?

results.headline_credit_for_label:
Australia, 2020

Aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video. Indefinite loop.
results.description:
Exploding fireworks, bubbles in the atmosphere, an untouched swimming pool.

Small everyday moments of existence are presented across 60 screens as a complex cacophony of events in CATARACT (concrete). This dynamic and overwhelming assemblage of images reflects the abundance of moments and messages we encounter in the world, which is represented as a complex and synthesised totality. But with so much happening, how do we focus on a singular experience and create meaning?

That is the central question von Sturmer raises in this multi-screen work, which uses impromptu recordings and tabletop experiments to invite the viewer to negotiate between singular moments and discordant fragments of experience.
description_for_label:
Exploding fireworks, bubbles in the atmosphere, an untouched swimming pool.

Small everyday moments of existence are presented across 60 screens as a complex cacophony of events in CATARACT (concrete). This dynamic and overwhelming assemblage of images reflects the abundance of moments and messages we encounter in the world, which is represented as a complex and synthesised totality. But with so much happening, how do we focus on a singular experience and create meaning?

That is the central question von Sturmer raises in this multi-screen work, which uses impromptu recordings and tabletop experiments to invite the viewer to negotiate between singular moments and discordant fragments of experience.

results.title: Faster pussycat kill, kill. Mondo topless
results.creator_credit: Russ Meyer, Eve Meyer and Eve Productions
results.brief_description: Russ Meyer made famous this b-grade exploitation style of popular culture and in his films explored the people living on the edge or outside of the mainstream culture of the day. “Faster Pussycat Kill! Kill!” a cult classic centres around three women who are on a wild rampage of violence and revenge, a new breed of violence where sex is it’s favourite mantle and terrorizing people the order of the day. These “homicidal go-go’s” start their journey with a drag race across the desert followed by a violent showdown with local ranchers. The film is filled with hard-line one-liners, for example in answering the question “What’s the point?” the ringleader vixen Varla (Tura Satana) replies “The point is of no return, and you’ve just crossed it”. The second film “Mondo Topless” equally a cult classic is a montage of topless go-go dancers accompanied with voice overs from the dancers talking about their trade, motivations and views of their sexuality.

results.title: Alice Elliott
results.brief_description: The Promo Indians are among the world’s finest basket-makers. Alice Elliott is one of a few Promo continuing this centuries-old tradition.

results.title: Appeal
results.brief_description:
Edith lives alone with her cat, unhappy with her looks and her life, when media influence and an accident involving a peeler set her on a path to transform her body image. Initial improvement to Edith’s wellbeing is tragically compromised by obsession.

Film explores issues surrounding self image and eating disorders.

This work was created as part of coursework at the Centre for Animation and Interactive Media (AIM), RMIT.

results.title: Australian super 8 films 1981-1986
results.brief_description: The early 1980s saw an emergence of a Super 8 film culture. The three hour compilation tape features 27 Super 8 films produced by Australian artists between 1981 and 1986. It attempts to be a representative survey of prominent filmmakers, themes and style. A rare and important documentation of a fertile aspect of Australian film and visual arts activities. Curated by Michael Hutak, Super 8 Group Australia.
